messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:07): notes that Opera violates the HTML5 requirement that UAs MUST NOT support UTF-7
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (10:17): what's the reason for forbidding UTF-7?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (10:17): other than it being a totally useless encoding for the web
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:23): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: it is a security problem, too
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:26): kig: I'm not planning to do that
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:33): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, what's the scenario?

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:36): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: an attacker injects UTF-7 encoded evil code into a forum. the forum software assumes that Basic Latin and ASCII bytes have a sane correspondence and doesn't filter out the evil attack code.

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:37): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: the user is somehow tricked to selecting UTF-7 (e.g. by simply posting an instruction to do so; so gullible people will fall for it).
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:37): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: the attack code runs
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (10:39): Firefox supports UTF-7 too
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:40): Safari doesn't let you pick UTF-7 from the encoding menu in the UI at least
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:40): though I dunno if it supports it generally
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:41): 8-bit encodings where ASCII is not ASCII are bad mojo
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:41): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I think there's a bug about disabling UTF-7 from Gecko wherever feasible
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (10:42): it's most insecure when auto-detect is enabled and allowed to switch to UTF-7 automatically
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:44): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=408457
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:44): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=406777
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:46): has very little sympathy for authors whose sites would break due to UTF-7 getting disabled
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (10:46): I wonder how many sites are actually using UTF-7
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:47): probably in the same ballpark with UTF-32 usage
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:48): is there an easy way to test whether an encoding is ebcdic-based?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:48): UTF-32 is not used
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:48): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: it is by test suites, I believe

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:48): yeah, test suites caused us to support it iirc
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:49): coming up with new character encodings should carry an even more drastic punishment than coming up with new C++ features
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (10:49): if it's only test suites using it, then that's not real world usage and it can be dropped

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:07): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: perhaps. I'll put in on the banned list.

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:10): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: according to my test code, ASCII bytes decode to corresponding Basic Lating in Big5 and GB2312
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (11:11): well, if that's what you mean by ASCII based...
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (11:11): then Unicode is ASCII based too :-)
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (11:11): The mappings for bytes 00-7F are actually not specified by Big5 or GB2312 or comparable encodings
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (11:12): they're just "whatever the system does"
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:12): oh. that's bad
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (11:12): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big5
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:12): ASCII is de facto, though, isn't it?

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (11:12): "The modern characterization of Big5 as an MBCS consisting of the DBCS of Big5 plus the SBCS of ASCII is therefore historically incorrect and potentially flawed, as the choice of the matching SBCS was, and theoretically still is, quite independent of the flavour of Big5 being used."
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:13): I care about the IANA meaning and actual Web usage

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:15): more specifically, I'm right now implementing checking for the HTML5 requirements about encodings implementations MUST NOT support, authors SHOULD NOT use and the ASCII superset requirement
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:16): Hixie: you have a definition for ASCII supersetness but you don't say how to tell if an encoding is EBCDIC-based

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:18): It seems that the stuff on my non-ASCII list consists of UTF-16, UTF-32, ISCII, legacy dingbat stuff, a couple of Japanese and Korean encodings and an insane number of IBM encodings
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:18): it looks almost safe to whitelist UTF-16 and complain about all other non-ASCII-superset encodings

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:21): hmm. or perhaps this heuristic works for non-x-encodings: if non-ASCII-superset and name starts with "cp" or "ibm", the encoding falls under the EBCDIC SHOULD NOT
